sentenceInfoList.sentence: ERA el rey de Toledo el moro Almenón, con quien el rey de Castilla don Fernando el Grande mantenía cordial amistad.
Este rey moro tenía una hija muy hermosa y compasiva, llamada Casilda.
Una esclava castellana contó á la hija del rey moro que los nazarenos amaban á su Dios, y á su rey, y á sus padres, y á sus hermanos, y á sus esposas.

También contó la esclava á la hija del rey moro, que los nazarenos nunca quedan huérfanos de madre, porque cuando pierden á la que los concibió, les queda otra, llamada María, que es una madre inmortal.
Pasaron años, pasaron años, y Casilda fué creciendo en cuerpo y en hermosura y en virtud.
Se le murió su madre, y envidió la dicha de los huérfanos nazarenos.
En los confines del jardín que rodeaba el palacio del rey moro, había unas lóbregas mazmorras, donde gemían, hambrientos y cargados de cadenas, muchos cautivos cristianos.
Sucedió que un día fué Casilda á pasear por los jardines de su padre, y oyó gemir á los pobres cautivos.
La princesa mora tornó al palacio, lleno su corazón de tristeza.

longDef: Yo soy de los Estados Unidos. ― I am from the United States.

Errar es humano. ― To err is human.
2007, El Sueño de Morfeo, Nada es Suficiente:

¿Qué voy a ser si te he dado lo que soy? ― What am I going to be if I've given you what I am?
2007, El Sueño de Morfeo, Para Toda la Vida:
Si fueras una gota de agua, nadie volvería a tener sed ― If you were a drop of water, no one would thirst again
(Verb) to be (in the passive voice sense)
La guitarra fue tocada. ― The guitar was played.
(Article) feminine singular definite article used before nouns which start with a stressed /a/:
el alma, las almas ― the soul, the souls
el hacha, las hachas ― the axe, the axes
(Preposition) of; 's; used after the thing owned and before the owner
Constitución española de 1812 ― Spanish constitution of 1812
la cola del perro ― the dog’s tail
(Preposition) from (with the source or provenance of or at)
Soy de España. ― I’m from Spain.
The name of the Latin-script letter D.
(Noun) (colloquial) a Muslim or Arab, particularly Muslims in the southern Philippines
first-person singular present indicative of morar
(Verb) to reside, to dwell, to abide
Yo cuento con ustedes. ― I count on you.
La mujer con quien se casó ― The woman whom he married
La persona a quien yo amo ― The person whom I love
(Noun) a title of respect to a man, prefixed to first names
[Y] dime: don Luis Mejías ¿ha venido hoy? ― [A]nd tell me: mister Luis Mejía, did he come today?

grande.shortDef: (after the noun or predicatively) big, large
longDef: (Adjective) (after the noun or predicatively) big, large
Synonyms: (for cloth, shoe, place) amplio, voluminoso
Mantenga la tapa cerrada, por favor. ― Keep the lid closed, please.
Yo mantengo a mis hijos. ― I support my children.
uh, well (space filler in a conversation)
Ella tiene seis hermanos. ― She has six brothers.
Tengo una pluma. ― I have a pen.
(Verb) (transitive) to have, possess, to be (a condition or quality)
Usted tiene suerte. ― You are lucky. (literally, "You have luck.")
¿Quién tiene razón? ― Who is right? (literally, "Who has reason?")
Una manzana al día mantiene al médico en lejanía. - An apple a day keeps the doctor away.
Sólo hay una ruta - There is only one route.
Tengo un coche muy caro. ― I have a very expensive car.

y.shortDef:
and
1605, Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, Don Quijote de la Mancha1, Chapter I:
longDef: Es, pues, de saber que este sobredicho hidalgo, los ratos que estaba ocioso —que eran los más del año—, se daba a leer libros de caballerías, con tanta afición y gusto, que olvidó casi de todo punto el ejercicio de la caza y aun la administración de su hacienda; y llegó a tanto su curiosidad y desatino en esto, que vendió muchas hanegas de tierra de sembradura para comprar libros de caballerías en que leer, y, así, llevó a su casa todos cuantos pudo haber dellos. ― You must know, then, that the above-named gentleman whenever he was at leisure (which was mostly all the year round) gave himself up to reading books of chivalry with such ardour and avidity that he almost entirely neglected the pursuit of his field-sports, and even the management of his property; and to such a pitch did his eagerness and infatuation go that he sold many an acre of tillageland to buy books of chivalry to read, and brought home as many of them as he could get.
(Noun) Castilian Spanish (the dialect of the kingdom or region of Castile)
Castilian (of or related to the kingdom or region of Castile)
(inexact, sometimes offensive) Spanish (of or related to Spain, particularly the Castilian or European forms of the Spanish language)
accusative of ella, ello (when the antecedent's implied gender is feminine), and usted (when referring to a woman); her, it, you (formal)
impersonal neuter pronoun (accusative) in certain colloquial phrases: it, this
La sabe toda.  ― He/she knows everything (it all)
¡Dónde la viste!  ― Where have you seen this!
No te la creo.  ― I don't believe you.
(Contraction) of the, from the (+ a masculine noun in singular).
Él dice que está triste. ― He says that he is sad.
Llego más tarde que tú. ― I am arriving later than you.
la estrella que está en la película ― the star who is in the movie
la mujer con la que yo hablé ― the woman with whom I spoke
Accusative form of ellos or ustedes
Plural masculine or neuter pronoun, e.g. los que no hablan, "those who do not speak"
(Noun) someone from Dos Hermanas, a city in Seville
from Dos Hermanas, a city in Seville
(Verb) to love, have great affection for, care about
Su casa es grande. - His house is big.
Su madre es muy simpática. - Her mother is very nice.
¿Cómo está su familia? - How is your family?
¿Dónde está su coche? - Where is your car?

hermano.shortDef:
brother
1970, "Los Hermanos", Atahualpa Yupanqui (lyrics), performed by Atahualpa Yupanqui:
longDef: Yo tengo tantos hermanos / Que no los puedo contar / Y una novia muy hermosa / Que se llama Libertad ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
first-person singular present indicative of hermanar
Y tu mamá también ― And your mother, as well.
también lo hace el / la… ― so does the…

Nunca he probado la langosta. ― I've never tasted lobster.
2008, Fausto Ponce, Fuera de lugar, Lulu.com, page 7:
Nunca te va a hacer una chingadera. ― He will never screw you over.
Estamos mejor que nunca. ― We're better than ever.
(Verb) (intransitive) to be (as a result of something)
quedar de acuerdo ― to be in agreement (as a result of a discussion)
Quedo contento con el coche. ― I am pleased with the car (after buying it).
Las ciudades quedaron destruidas por la guerra. ― The cities were destroyed as a result of the war.
(Verb) (intransitive) to be situated; to be located (used with only static objects, such as buildings)
Synonyms: encontrarse en, estar ubicado en
Queda muy lejos. ― It is too far.
Queda por allí. ― It's over there.
Nuestra tienda queda en la Alameda Central. ― Our store is located on Central Boulevard.
Ven cuando estés listo. ― Come when you're ready.
No quiero perderme nada. ― I don't want to miss anything.

le.shortDef: To her, for her (dative form of ella)
longDef: To her, for her (dative form of ella)
To him, for him (dative form of él)
To you, for you (dative form of usted, ello, lo)

l.shortDef: The 12th letter of the Spanish alphabet
longDef: The 12th letter of the Spanish alphabet

otra.shortDef: feminine of otro; another, another one
longDef: feminine of otro; another, another one
(Noun) (historical) Former coin of Spain in the 17th century, equivalent to 12 reales de vellón

pasar.shortDef: to pass, to spend (time), to happen
longDef: (Verb) (transitive) to pass, to hand, to slip
estas cosas pasan ― these things happen
Ya me ha pasado. ― It has already happened to me.
el año que viene ― next year
el año vigente ― the current year
va para un año que no te veo ― it's been a year since I saw you
con los años me cuesta cada vez más estar feliz ― over the years I find it harder and harder to be happy
dentro de un par de años ― in a couple of years' time
el mejor año de mi vida ― the best year of my life
todos los años es igual ― it's the same thing year on year
en sus años mozo ― in her childhood years
Tengo veinte años. ― I'm twenty [years old].
Depende de los años que tenga. ― It depends how old it is.
Estoy en casa. ― I'm at home.
Estoy sentado en la computadora. ― I'm sitting at the computer.
en esta página ― on this page
en la caja en la mesa ― in the box on the table

cuerpo.shortDef: body (the physical structure of a human or animal)
longDef: (Noun) body (the physical structure of a human or animal)
(Noun) beauty (the quality of being attractive or pleasing)

se.shortDef: third person (also used for usted and ustedes) reflexive direct or indirect object oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
longDef: (Pronoun) third person (also used for usted and ustedes) reflexive direct or indirect object oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
Juan se lava. ― Juan washes himself.
Juan se lava la cara. ― Juan washes his own face. (literally, "Juan to himself washes the face.")
Juan y María se aman. ― Juan and María love each other.
(Pronoun) used to convey the meaning of the English passive voice in the third person and with usted and ustedes
¿Cómo se llama? ― What is your name? (literally, "How do you call yourself?")
Se dice que... ― It is said that... (literally, "It says itself that...")
Aquí se habla español ― Spanish is spoken here / They speak Spanish here. (literally, "One speaks Spanish here, Spanish speaks itself here.")
Synonyms: estirar la pata, fallecer, morirse, palmar, petatearse
La caballerosidad no ha muerto. ― Chivalry is not dead.
(Verb) (transitive) to confine, to limit, to restrict, to keep within bounds
(Verb) (transitive) to lock down, to secure (make people stay locked indoors for their safety)

haber.shortDef: to have (to do something, auxiliary verb)
longDef: (Verb) (auxiliary verb taking past participle to build various perfect tenses) to have
He trabajado muy duro durante este mes. ― I have worked very hard during this month.
Mi hermanito me pidió más chocolate, pero ya le había dado demasiado. ― My little brother asked me for more chocolate, but I had already given him too much.

unir.shortDef: to connect, to unite, to join, to bind, to attach
longDef: ¡Únete al sindicato! ― Join up with the union!

Synonym: calabozo
2023 February 10, Iker Seisdedos, "Relatos de la peor mazmorra de Nicaragua: "Nos engrillaban para dormir o cuando nos llevaban al ‘túnel’. Allí te esperaban los golpes"", in El País‎[1]:

El Infiernillo carga la fama de ser la peor mazmorra de Managua. Allí, en esa cárcel de máxima seguridad, Solís, estudiante de Derecho, pasó tres años en régimen de aislamiento, en un "camarote sin luz solar, con la puerta siempre sellada". ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
El lugar donde estamos es secreto. ― The place where we are is secret.
(in indirect questions) where, in what place
Deja los libros donde quieras. ― Leave the books where you want.
Estamos donde la plaza mayor. ― We're around by the main square.
Cenamos donde Daniel. ― We're having dinner (round) at Daniel's place.
Yo no tengo pan y estoy hambriento. ― I do not have bread and I'm hungry.

hungry
1657, Baltasar Gracián, "En el invierno de la vejez", in El Criticón, tercera parte:
No gusta de los manjares sino el hambriento, y el sediento de la bebida. ― Nobody enjoys tasteful morsels but who is hungry, and beverages who is thirsty.

cadena.shortDef: chain (series of interconnected rings or links usually made of metal)
longDef: (Noun) chain (series of interconnected rings or links usually made of metal)
(Noun) necklace (article of jewelry that is worn around the neck)

muchos.shortDef: much; many (of something) (masculine plural of mucho, much)
longDef: much; many (of something) (masculine plural of mucho, much)
first-person singular present indicative of cautivar
first-person singular present indicative of cristianar
(Verb) to happen, to befall, to occur
Suceda lo que suceda ― Come what may.
¡Mira al cielo, hay un águila! - Look at the sky, there's an eagle!
¡Manos arriba, tengo un arma! - Hands up, I have a gun!
(Noun) day (a period from midnight to the following midnight)

El resto della concluían sayo de velarte, calzas de velludo para las fiestas, con sus pantuflos de lo mesmo, y los días de entresemana se honraba con su vellorí de lo más fino. ― The rest of it went in a doublet of fine cloth and velvet breeches and shoes to match for holidays, while on week-days he made a brave figure in his best homespun.

pasear.shortDef: (intransitive) to stroll, to saunter, to promenade
longDef: (Verb) (intransitive) to stroll, to saunter, to promenade
(Verb) (intransitive) to walk, to take a walk
Lo hice por ti. - I did it for you.
Escrito por Juan. - Written by Juan.
Entra por la puerta principal. - Enter through the main door.
Oí ruidos extraños viniendo desde detrás de la puerta y tuve miedo. ― I heard strange noises coming from behind the door and got scared.

Mi pobre vecino siempre está llorando. ― My poor neighbor is always crying.
2013, El sueño el Morfeo, Vuelve (a donde has venido):

El pasado ya es pasado, no tienes que pedir perdón. Solo déjanos tranquilos a mí y a mi pobre corazón. ― The past is the past, you don't have to ask forgiveness. Just leave us alone, me and my poor heart.
(Adjective) (after the noun) poor (lacking money, resources, etc.)
Se relajan las familias ricas en casas lujosas y las familias pobres tiran en chozas desmoronadas. ― The rich families relax in luxurious houses and the poor families get by in dilapidated huts.
default (failure to meet an obligation on time)
(Verb) (intransitive) to come back; to go back

Synonyms: regresar, retornar, volver
1877, Benito Pérez Galdós, Gloria:
Como además vieron al doctor Sedeño abstraído en la lectura de los periódicos políticos, tornaron al jardín. ― (please add an English translation of this quotation)
(Contraction) Contraction of a el ("at the, to the").
first-person singular present indicative of llenar
(Verb) (transitive) to fill out or complete a form
Por favor llene este formulario. ― Please fill out this form.

tristeza.shortDef: sadness, gloom, sorrow, gloominess, unhappiness, misery
longDef: (Noun) sadness, gloom, sorrow, gloominess, unhappiness, misery

title: ERA el rey de Toledo el moro Almenón, con quien el rey de Castilla don Fernando el Grande mantenía cordial amistad.
